phrase.description: We still have to check the lexical tones.

phrase.translation: kwaku has not bought the house
phrase.description: In the negative, it is the perfect marker but in the affirmative, it is a past tense marker. What happens is that, what is usually the past tense marker in the affirmative becomes a perfect marker in the negative and vice versa. So what we have in the above sentence is a perfect marker. KBA Again, am not so sure whether the sentence is from Fante or Twi because of the tones. If it is from Twi then the tones are incorrect. As I said earlier on, in isolation, that is how the tones would be realized but in a sentence like this, due to assimilation, the tones would change to [ń!tɔ́ɔ̀].

phrase.translation: The child ask a question
phrase.description: Verb frame? Can we distinguish He asks his friend (Vtr) from He is inquisitive? -DB The word for inquisitive is asɛmpɛ from the phrase pɛ asɛm literally meaning like (people's) matters. Thus, for the child is inquisitive, it will be 'abɔfra no pɛ asɛm'. The meaning for the above sentence could be the child likes asking questions or simply the child asks questions. KBA

phrase.translation: The child is not inquisitive
phrase.description:
the NEG morpheme totally assimilates the initial consonant of the verb stem making it 'mmisa'.
Is there an underlying form of the negative prefix? What makes 'bisa' habitual? Is it that all unmarked verbs are habitual?
It is obvious now that the writer is using Fante. But the problem is that she seems to be combining Twi and Fante words and even tones. In Fante there is no nasal assimilation so 'mbisa' is correct. But in Twi there is nasal assimilation so the /b/ would change to /m/ as you have stated. The underlying form for the nasal prefix is the alveolar nasal /n/ as in the base form. What makes the verb habitual is the tone on the verb. For some of them, both the habitual and the imperative forms are the same so there is no controversy. But there are some that the habitual and the imperative have different tones. In that case, some linguists consider the imperative to be the base form while other consider the habitual to be the base form. I always support those who consider the habitual to be the base. For the word 'bisa', the imperative form has LL while the habitual has LH. In Fante, the habitual has a HL tone pattern as seen above. I think the final tone should be H in asɛm even in Fante. KBA

phrase.translation: He or she did not buy the house
phrase.description:
Tone marking missing. What is the function of the 'a' prefix?
The tones provided are Asante Twi tones; not Fante. That prefix is marking past tense. As I indicated earlier, in the affirmative the past tense marker is a suffix but in the negative it is a prefix, specifically /a/ while the perfect marker is the prefix /a/ in the affirmative and a suffix; and it behaves the same way the past tense marker behaves in the affirmative.

phrase.translation: Kwaku kneels there
phrase.description:
What make 'koto' durative? hɔ seems a locative pronoun (a deictic pronoun - not near to speaker) Is that correct? Why is it marked as manner adverb? _DB
You are right, hɔ is a locative pronoun which means there. However, sometimes, a speak can use it even when his/her addressee is closer by as in: fa to hɔ 'put it down' or even koto hɔ 'knee down' or 'knee there' or 'squat'
Am not so sure about the DUR; what I can say is that, depending on the tones on the verb, koto, it could be Habitual or stative. Looking at the free translation, we can say the verb is in the stative form. Also I don't understand why the vowels changed from /o/ to /u/. I think the vowels should be /o/ but not /u/. Thus, the word should be koto and not kutu.

phrase.translation: Kwaku is buying the house.
phrase.description: The tones on the verb are not correct. Either we get rètɔ́ for Twi or rétɔ̀ for Fante. If we use the Fante tones, the verb should change to rótɔ̀ due to the rounding harmony process in Fante. However, if we use the Twi tones, then kwákù should change to kwàkú.

phrase.translation: Kwaku will buy the house
phrase.description: Again, either we change the verb from bɛ´tɔ´ to bótɔ́ (Fante) or we change kwákù to kwàkú (Twi)

phrase.description:
There seem to be a tone missing on 'no'. Here the final vowel of the verb is annotated as the PAST. We have to make up our mind which system we would like to use.
Would you be comfortable with Boadi's system? - DB Do you mean the way he glosses his sentences? KBA
The base form of the verb 'to meet' is "hyia" not "kye" This should be the sentence: kòfí hyìáà nò. I think the past tense morpheme should show. What we have now can only mean 'Kofi greets him/her'. The past tense form would be Kofi kyeaa no 'Kofi greeted him/her'

phrase.translation: The month has ended
phrase.description: What is the meaning of 'so'? Is it the same up as in "The cat is up on the table"? -DB 'so' in this instance is related to time; that is, 'the time is up'. In this context, the 'free translation' should be 'the month has ended'. If I want to say 'your time is up' in Akan, it would be 'wo bere aso'. So you can see that this is not the same as ' is up on the table' but 'has ended' or 'has elapsed' . The prefix 'a' is a perfect marker, not 'be' These are the tones: Bòsó!mé á!só

phrase.translation: this christmas, I will travel
I will travel this christmas
I will travel this christmas
phrase.description:
Is 'tu' used regularity to express the future?
The verb 'tu' has multiple meanings. It could mean to uproot, to move, to fly, to take, etc. The actual meaning will therefore depend on the environment or its complement. The above sentence is not correct because of the determiner 'yi'. If we take away the adjunct 'bronya yi', the sentence will mean 'I travel' (HAB). That is, when 'tu' collocates with 'kwan' (meaning 'road' or 'way') it means 'to travel'.
The problem I see here is that, when the first person subject 'me' occurs with a verb with the future marker 'bɛ', the vowel in the pronoun is deleted, and the consonant in the future marker 'b' is also deleted. Thus, the sentence should be "mɛtu " (underlyingly, me-bɛ-tu). However, due to Vowel Harmony, the 'ɛ' is perceived as 'e' in speech; but the orthography is 'ɛ' not 'e'. Thus, this would would be the one with tones: m-ɛ́-tú !kwáń búrònyà yí. 'I will travel this Christmas.'

phrase.translation: There are many towns along the road that links Trondheim and Oslo

phrase.original: Joy saa fɛfɛfɛ wɔ dwabɔ no ase
phrase.translation: Joy danced beautifully at the durbar

phrase.original: ɔbaa bi bɛtɔn nneɛma wɔ ha
phrase.translation: A woman comes to sell things here
phrase.description:
?? not clear what "wɔ" is here
"wɔ" seems to indicate a location.

phrase.translation: Kaja loves the students
Kaja loves the student
look at the dress
search for the dress
The children are dead

phrase.original: Ama bɔɔ ɛpono no mu panpan nanso obiara angye so
phrase.translation: Ama knocked hard on the door but no one responded

phrase.original: Da bi, ananse kɔtuu bayerɛ akɛsie dɛdɛbi firi n'afuo mu
phrase.translation: One day, Spider went to uproot some big and tasty yams from his farm
phrase.description: Tu means dig but in this context, it refers to uprooting yam from the soil. You more or less dig the soil before you can uproot the yam

phrase.original: ɔnyaa abotare totoo bayerɛ no ma na etu hwa yie
phrase.translation: He patiently roasted the yam and it smelled very well
phrase.description:
I annotated ma as a causative because the yam smelled real good because of the care with which Ananse roasted the yam. ie, that caused the yam to smell good. I also glossed the 'tu' in 'etu' to mean fly because the smell saturates in the air. Tu can mean both dig or fly
?? no so sure about the underlying form of 'e'

phrase.original: ɛsiane sɛ na ɛyɛ dɛ nti na ɔpɛ sɛ odi no ntɛm
phrase.translation: because it was sweet, he wanted to eat it quickly
phrase.description: ?? The use of "sɛ" in this sentence is unclear.

phrase.original: Ankyɛ biara na ɔtee sɛ obi rebɔ ne pono mu
phrase.translation: Not long afterwards, he heard that someone was knocking at his door
phrase.description:
?? what is the meaning of -a in ankyɛ.
might be a nominalisation -DB

phrase.original: Na ɛyɛ akyekyedeɛ na ɔrebɔ pono no mu
phrase.translation: It was turtle who was knocking at the door
phrase.description: ?? Here "na" seems to be a form of the relative pronoun "a"

phrase.original: Na akyekyedeɛ firi akwantuo mu nti na waberɛ
phrase.translation: Turtle was returning from a journey so he was tired
phrase.description: ?? Wo= you

phrase.original: Afei nso na ɛkɔm de no yie
phrase.translation: And also he was very hungry
phrase.description: I think afei is more of an additive particle/marker. Not so sure but I have to consult a few people to get the exact gloss

phrase.original: Akyekyedeɛ kakyerɛɛ ananse sɛ ɔnam na bayerɛ bi pampan faa ne hwene mu
phrase.translation: Turtle told spider that he was walking around and he smelled the scent/aroma of yam
phrase.description: pampan can refer to scent or aroma

phrase.original: na esiane sɛ ɛkɔm de no nti
phrase.translation: and because he is hungry

phrase.original: ɔyɛɛ n'adwene sɛ ɔbɛba abɛserɛ no
phrase.translation: he made up his mind that he will come and beg him

phrase.original: sɛ ɔbɛma no bi adi a
phrase.translation: if he will give him some to eat

phrase.original: Na ɛyɛ amaneɛ wɔ kurom hɔ sɛ sɛ obi srɛ wo aduane a
phrase.translation: It was a custom in the town that if someone begs you for food...
phrase.description:
sɛ....a is the conditional marker 'if'
??"wo" is 2SG

phrase.original: ɛsɛ sɛ wo ma no bi
phrase.translation: you have to give him/her some
phrase.description: ɛsɛ means it is right or cultural. so in this case it is right or cultural to give him/her some

phrase.original: enti na ananse ntumi nka sɛ daabi
phrase.translation: so ananse could not say no
phrase.description: ?? also here to call "na" a onjunctions seems not describe its function correctly. -DB

phrase.translation: ananse is greedy

phrase.original: nti na ɔmpɛ sɛ ɔma akyekyedeɛ bayerɛ no bi di.
phrase.translation: so he did not want to give turtle some of the yam to eat
phrase.description: ?? The use of "na" here seems to be cause by the sentence initial PRT. Hard to call this a conjunction really.

phrase.original: ɔbɔɔ pɔ wɔ ne tiri mu sɛ ɔmma no ndi bayerɛ no bi.
phrase.translation: he made a point in his mind that he will not allow turtle to eat some of the yam
phrase.description:
ɔbɔɔ pɔ..is like an idiom which means to plan something in one's mind
Your annotation of "no bi" makes one believe that Akan can have two determiners in the row, which is following standard wisdom is 'strange'. - Partitive NP

phrase.original: Ananse buee ɛpono no ma akyekyedeɛ wuraa ɛdan no mu
phrase.translation: Ananse opened the door for turtle to enter the room

phrase.original: Na ɔmaa no akonwa tenaa so
phrase.translation: and he gave him a chair to sit on (it)

phrase.original: Akyekyedeɛ tenee ne nsa sɛ ɔrebɛyi bayerɛ no bi pɛ
phrase.translation: Just as turtle stretched his hand to remove some of the yam,

phrase.original: na ananse teaa no kaa sɛ
phrase.translation: and spider shouted at him saying that

phrase.original: "wonnim sɛ yɛhohoro yɛnsa ansa na yadidi"
phrase.translation: dont you know that we wash our hands before we eat?
Turtle looked at his palms

phrase.original: ampa nso na emu ayɛ fi paa yie
phrase.translation: Truly, it was very dirty
phrase.description:
I gloss emu as a reflexive pronoun because it refers back to his (turtle) hands.
Akan has a series of reflexive pronouns. See the work by Kofi Saah. The above is not one of them.

phrase.original: nti ɔsɔree sɛ kɔɔ nsuo bi a na ɛda hɔ ho
phrase.translation: so he got up and went to a river that lied there
that he was going to wash his hands

phrase.original: ɔsan baa dan no mu no na ananse ahyɛaseɛ redi aduane no
phrase.translation: when he came back to the room, ananse had already started to eat the food
Ananse told turtle that...

phrase.original: na ɔmpɛ sɛ aduane no bɛdwo
phrase.translation: he didnt want the food to get cold

phrase.original: nti na ɔhyɛɛ aseɛ dii aduane no
phrase.translation: so he started to eat the food
phrase.description: hyɛɛaseɛ is a compound made up of hyɛ and aseɛ. It means to begin or start

phrase.original: nti sɛ waba deɛ a obetumi abɛdi bi
phrase.translation: so he can come and eat some
Turtle sat down again

phrase.original: nanso ɔsan tenee ne nsa sɛ ɔreyi aduane no bi pɛ
phrase.translation: but again, when he stretched his hand to take some of the food...
phrase.description:
pɛ...I have use this morpheme in a lot in this narrative and I think it best refers to "as soon as"¨
??"san" is sometimes called a V and sometimes an Adverb.

phrase.original: na ananse san tea mu bisaa no...
phrase.translation: spider again shouted and asked him ...

phrase.original: enti wante sɛ yɛnfa nsa fin ndidi
phrase.translation: so didn't you hear that we dont eat with dirty hands

phrase.original: Akyekyedeɛ hwɛɛ ne nsa mu huu sɛ asan ayɛ fin biom
phrase.translation: turtle looked at his hands and saw that it had become dirty again

phrase.original: nti ɔsɔre san kɔɔ nsuo no ho sɛ ɔrekɔhohoro ne nsa.
phrase.translation: so he got up again to go to the river side to wash his hands

phrase.original: esiane sɛ na ɔmpɛ sɛ ne nsa mu bɛyɛ fin biom no nti
phrase.translation: because he didnt want his hands to become dirty again so

phrase.original: ɔwieeɛ no ɔnantee nsensan no so baa nakyi
phrase.translation: when he finished, he walked on the grass on his way back

phrase.original: sɛ deɛ ɛbɛyɛ a ne nsa mu nyɛ fin biom.
phrase.translation: so that his hands will not become dirty again

phrase.original: Awerɛhosɛm ne sɛ oduruu dan no mu no
phrase.translation: sadly, when he got to the room...

phrase.original: na ananse adi aduane no awie.
phrase.translation: and spider had finished eating the food

phrase.original: Anokwa ɛhyee akyekyedeɛ yie nanso wanka hwee.
phrase.translation: Truly, it pained turtle but he didnt say anything

phrase.original: ɔhwɛɛ ananse anim kakra na ɔdaa no ase .
phrase.translation: he looked at ananse briefly and thanked him

phrase.original: ɔkakyerɛɛ ananse sɛ berɛ biara ɔbɛfa ne fie ho no ...
phrase.translation: he told spider that anytime he passes around his house ...

phrase.original: ɛyɛ a ɔnwura mu na ɔmbɛdidi
phrase.translation: he should come in to eat

phrase.original: Adufuropɛ nti, akyekyedeɛ asɛm no yɛɛ ananse dɛ
phrase.translation: Because of greed, turtle's issue (the dinner invitation) made spider happy

phrase.original: Dakoro bi, ɔyɛɛ n'adwenen sɛ ɔbɛkɔ akyekyedeɛ fie akɔdidi.
phrase.translation: one day, he made up his mind that he will go to turtle's house to eat

phrase.original: ɔkɔtoo sɛ akyekyedeɛ da nsuo bi ano reto awia
phrase.translation: he met turtle sunbathing at the bank of a river

phrase.original: Akyekyedeɛ pagyaa ne ti na ɔhuu ananse
phrase.translation: Turtle raised his head and saw spider

phrase.original: ɔmaa no akwaaba bisaa no sɛ aduane no nti na waba anaa
phrase.translation: he welcomed him and asked if he had come because of the food

phrase.original: ma ananse nso kaa sɛ aane
phrase.translation: cause spider to also say yes

phrase.original: Da no nso deɛ na ɛkɔm de ananse yie
phrase.translation: as for that day, spider was very hungry

phrase.original: Akyekyedeɛ kɔɔ ne fie wɔ nsuo no ase kɔtoo pono kamakama bi
phrase.translation: Turtle went to his house which was under the river to set a very nice table

phrase.original: Ankyɛ biara na opue baa nsuo no ani
phrase.translation: It didnt take a long time and he came to the surface of the water

phrase.original: bɛkakyerɛɛ ananse sɛ aduane no abene nti ɔmbɛdidi
phrase.translation: came to tell spider that he should come and eat
phrase.description: ?? what is the meaning of "bene"

phrase.original: ɛhɔ ara na akyekyedeɛ too ne ho wuraa nsuo no ase
phrase.translation: just then, spider threw himself into the water (spider dived into the water)

phrase.original: hyɛɛ aseɛ sɛ ɔredi aduane no
phrase.translation: started to eat the food

phrase.original: Ananse nso too neho sɛ ɔrewura nsuo no ase
phrase.translation: Ananse also dived into the water but ...

phrase.original: nanso esiane sɛ nemu yɛ hare no nti
phrase.translation: but because he is not heavy
phrase.description: hare...means not heavy or something that has a light weight

phrase.translation: he couldnt go under it

phrase.original: ɔyɛɛ biara nanso na ntumi nwura nsuo no mu
phrase.translation: He did everything but he wasnt able to enter the water (go under the water)

phrase.original: ne nyinaa akyi nso na akyekyedeɛ deɛ ɔredi aduane no
phrase.translation: and beside it all turtle was eating the food

phrase.original: Ananse twaa ne ho twaa ne ho saa
phrase.translation: spider turned himself around several times
phrase.description: twaa ne ho is repeated twice to indicate that ananse performed da action repeatedly

phrase.original: na afei adwene bi baa ne tiri mu
phrase.translation: and then an idea came to his mind
phrase.description: adwene means brain but it is used in a different sense to mean idea. Ideas come/occur in one's brain or mind

phrase.original: ɔhyɛɛ aseɛ sesaa aboɔ guu gyakɛti bi a na ɛhyɛ no mu
phrase.translation: he started to pick stones and put them in a jacket he was wearing
made him heavy (caused him to become heavy)

phrase.original: Esiane sɛ ne mu yɛɛ duru no nti
phrase.translation: because he was heavy

phrase.original: otumi too neho too nsuo no ase.
phrase.translation: he was able to go(throw himself) under the water
he went and sat at the table
phrase.description: ɛpono can refer to both table and door.

phrase.translation: and there was a lot of food on it
phrase.description: ??reduplication "beberee"? Food in English is a mass noun, food but not *foods Akan does not seem to make this distinction.

phrase.original: Ananse faa aduane no bi sɛ ɔrebɛdi ara pɛ na akyekyedeɛ kaa sɛ ɔntwɛn
phrase.translation: spider took some of the food to eat then turtle told him to wait
phrase.description: ??I doubt that the nasal in "ɔntwɛn" is a 3SG pronoun. ?? "...bi sɛ..." a case of complementation?

phrase.translation: Turtle told him that....
as for his town
we dont wear a Jacket when we are eating
so except he removes it(he has to remove the jacket)

phrase.original: Ananse worɔɔ gyakɛti no ara pɛ
phrase.translation: As soon as spider removed the jacket
phrase.description: pɛ...I have use this morpheme in a lot in this narrative and I think it best refers to "as soon as"

phrase.original: Na ɛhurii no bɛtoo nsuo no ani
phrase.translation: and it pushed him to the surface/top of the water
when he looked under the water...

phrase.original: na akyekyedeɛ gu so redi aduane no
phrase.translation: turtle was still eating the food
It really pained ananse
but elders say...
phrase.description: mpaninfoɔ se sɛ wani te beberee a woma apɔnkye akye...This is an Akan proverb which advises people against trying to be "too smart"

phrase.original: sɛ wani te beberee a woma apɔnkye akye
phrase.translation: if you open the eyes too much you wish the goat a good morning
phrase.description: mpaninfoɔ se sɛ wani te beberee a woma apɔnkye akye...This is an Akan proverb which advises people against trying to be "too smart" Transliterally, it means if you open your eyes too much you will say good morning to the goat

phrase.original: Toto apono no mu ansa na wada
phrase.translation: close the doors before you sleep
phrase.description: Vdep "sleep" ?

phrase.original: Fiifi kɔpagyapagya nnadeɛ wɔ gyemʊ hɔ
phrase.translation: Fiifi goes to lift weights at the gym

phrase.original: miamia so ma no nyɛ merɛmerɛmerɛ
phrase.translation: compress it so that it will become very soft
Seal all the holes
I have paid all my debts

phrase.original: Tikyafoɔ no baa na yɛre seresere wɔn
phrase.translation: when the teachers come, then we will be laughing at them

phrase.original: Mehuu Commonwealth Hall mmranteɛ no, na wɔhyehyɛ ntaadeɛ nkɔkɔɔnkɔkɔɔ
phrase.translation: I saw the commonwealth hall guys. They were in red dresses (shirts)

phrase.original: Ne nsa mu yɛ merɛmerɛmerɛ sɛ akwadaa foforɔ nsa mu
phrase.translation: Her palms are as soft as that of a new born baby
He hit him like "kumkum"
Kofi does not live here
Ernest went to Ghana to marry

phrase.original: Papa no kaa nokware no kyerɛɛ ɔsɔfo no
phrase.translation: The man told the truth to the pastor

phrase.original: Ernest kɔɔ Ghana kɔ waree de ne yere baa Norway
phrase.translation: Ernest went to Ghana to marry and brought his wife to Norway
he gave him a chair to sit on it

phrase.original: mɛyɛ adwuma anya sika atɔ akokɔ anoa awe amee ada asɔre akɔ asɔre akɔbɔ mpae
phrase.translation: I will work to get money to buy chicken and cook it, fry it and chew it and get satisfied and sleep, wake up and go to church to pray

phrase.original: Ama faa sekan dɔɔ afuo no mu
phrase.translation: Ama took a cutlass and weeded the farm

phrase.original: ɔkyerɛma no bɔ twenee to nnwom
phrase.translation: The drummer plays the drum and sing

phrase.original: Ernest ntɔ ataadeɛ mma Ama nhyɛ
phrase.translation: Ernest will not buy a dress for ama to wear

phrase.original: Agyekum fa sekan twa nam we
phrase.translation: Agyekum takes a knife to cut meat and chew

phrase.original: Agyekum maa Akua sekan twaa nam wee
phrase.translation: Agyekum gave Akua a knife for her to cut meat to chew

phrase.original: Agyekum faa sekan twaa nam wee
phrase.translation: Agyekum took a knife to cut meat and chewed it

phrase.original: Tyson de twɛdeɛ bɔɔ Holyfield ani
phrase.translation: Tyson hit Holyfield's eyes with a blow

phrase.original: Ernest kɔɔ Ghana na kɔ waree
phrase.translation: Ernest went to Ghana and got married
Kofi has taken the money and gone
Kofi jumped and took the money
looked
phrase.description: transcription of hwehwɛɛ ɕɥɪ́ ɕɥɛ́ɛ̀

phrase.translation: I will look at him
I will look for him

phrase.original: ñàbeàrñá biá ñánnaà Oàwuàdiániá biá bñàteànaáaà kuàroá.
sɛ fufuo no anyɛ aba-aba a na nkwan no ayɛ nsuo-nsuo
phrase.translation: if the fufu does not become lumpy, the soup becomes soggy
Thousands of money cannot buy life

phrase.original: sɛ mpemmpem tan me a, mpemmpem na dɔ me
phrase.translation: If a thousand(people) hate mate, a thousand(people) love me
Arrange it into groups of three
They have arranged it in (groups of) four hundred
The car is nice
The nice car
The house is not nice
The ugly (not nice) house

phrase.original: Da koro na ɔkraman bi nenam hwehwɛ aduane.
phrase.translation: one day a dog was wandering around looking for food
he saw a butcher's shop

phrase.original: ntɛmtɛm ara no owuraa hɔ kowia dompe kɛse firi ɔpon no so.
phrase.translation: quickly he entered to steal a fatty juicy bone from the shelf

phrase.original: ɔwe dompe no anigye mu no ɔkɔpue kwae bi mu.
phrase.translation: happily chewing the bone he runs into a forest

phrase.original: ankyɛ na ɔbepue birigi bi ho.
phrase.translation: soon he came across a brige

phrase.original: ɔretwa birigi no ɔhwɛɛ nsu no mu.
phrase.translation: as he crossed the bridge he looked into the river
lo and behold what did he see

phrase.original: ohuu ɔkraman foforo a ɔtesɛ ɔno a dompe hyɛ nano.
phrase.translation: he saw another dog exactly as him holding a bone in his mouth

phrase.original: ɔkraman nibrefo yi yɛɛ nadwen sɛ ɔpɛ saa dompe no nso.
phrase.translation: the greedy dog decided he wanted that bone too

phrase.original: nti ɔpɔe dwen sɛ ɔkraman foforo no a ɔwɔ nsu no mu de ehu begyae dompe no mu.
phrase.translation: so he growled hoping that the other dog in the river will drop the bone out of fear

phrase.original: na wakɔfa saa dompe no de ndompe mmienu no adwane.
phrase.translation: he will then grab the other bone and run away with two bones

phrase.original: nanso ɔpɔɔ nea etwa toɔ sɛ ɔde hunahuna ɔkraman foforo no.
phrase.translation: but as he gave out a last snore to scare off the other dog

phrase.original: dompe no firi nano tɔɔ nsu no mu yirae.
phrase.translation: the bone fell from his mouth into the river, lost forever

phrase.original: ɔkraman no wɔ nanibremu faa ne sunsum wɔ nsu no mu sɛ ɔkraman foforo a okura dompe.
phrase.translation: the dog in his own greed took his own reflection in the river as another dog holding a bone

phrase.original: akyiri ohuu ne gyimmii de ɔkɔm ne abufo kɔe.
phrase.translation: he realised folly too late and walk away hungry and sad
perhaps a little wiser
The nice car
The food is sweet (delicious)
The sweet (delicious) food
The sweet food
phrase.description: The adjective dɛ cannot be used attributively, only the reduplicated form dɛdɛ can be given that function.

phrase.translation: The goat cries mɛɛmɛɛ
phrase.description: (imitating the natural cry of a goat)

phrase.translation: Barcelona's style of play is passing
phrase.description:
"akɔyɛ"......'tends to be' or 'is like'
bɔɔlobɔ...compound made up of bɔɔlo 'ball' and bɔ 'play' to refer to style of play. it functions as an adjective in this construction since it modifies the team Barcelona.
pepapepa.....ideophone imitating the sound made by passing the ball

phrase.original: drɔba no de nkakrankakra sanee bepɔ no
phrase.translation: The driver descended the mountain slowly (he drove slowly down the mountain)

phrase.original: ɔayɛ ne no nyaanyaa nanso ɔnyɛ
phrase.translation: He appears to be a calm person but he is not good

phrase.original: ɛyɛ fim a wɔato din simon agyinamoa.
phrase.translation: it is a film titled simon's cat

phrase.original: Papa bi te hɔ na nagyinamoa te ne so.
phrase.translation: a man is sitting with his cat sitting on him
a fly has come to pass

phrase.original: Agyinamoa no pɛ sɛ ɔkye hwansena no.
phrase.translation: the cat wants to catch the fly

phrase.original: ɔaka papa no tii agu fam.
phrase.translation: it has poured the man's tea on the flooor
it has gone to stand on the chair

phrase.original: agyinamoa no aka kanea no ato fam.
phrase.translation: the cat has
he wants to catch the fly

phrase.original: otwitwa nani nanso onhu hwansena no.
phrase.translation: it is looking round but it cannot find the fly
the cat has seen the fly
it is still searching for the fly

phrase.original: hwansena no akɔ si papa no atifi.
phrase.translation: the fly has gone to sit on top of the man's head

phrase.original: Agyinamoa no abɛkye no wɔ hɔ.
phrase.translation: the cat has come to catch it over there
the fly has ran away

phrase.original: Agyinamoa no de mirika di hwansena no akyi.
phrase.translation: the cat is running after the fly
the fly has decended down
the cat too has decended down
the cat has caught the fly

phrase.original: ɔde ne nsa bobɔ hwansena no.
phrase.translation: it is hitting the fly with the hand
the cat has killed the fly

phrase.original: agyinamoa no de hwansena no di agorɔ.
phrase.translation: the cat is playing with the fly

phrase.original: Agyinamoa no de hwansena no ahyɛ nanum.
phrase.translation: the cat has put the fly into his mouth

phrase.original: ɔaforo akonwa no akɔgyina simon nkɛn.
phrase.translation: it has climb the chair to go stand by simon

phrase.original: ɔpɛ sɛ onyane simon nanso simon ada.
phrase.translation: it wants to wake simon up but simon is asleep
now it has climb to go and stand on top of simon's head
simon is awake
The red dress
The red dresses

phrase.original: ñàbeàrñá biá ñánnaà Oàwuàdiániá biá bñàteànaáaà kuàroá biá màfiákyiáreá baàaàbiá kwaán muá
ÑÁnnaà õàheáneá noá aâ õàwõà kuàroá muá hõánoá
